loans.name: Tatyana

texts.en: Tatyana is a widow. She has two adult sons who left the family. Tatyana sells women's clothing at an open market in Berdyansk town. She has been in this business for 12 years and knows it well. Tatyana would like to purchase additional inventory for the current winter season. She hopes to receive additional income and improve her business conditions.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is 28 and a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past three years, she has operated a retail shop, selling to her neighbors and passersby. With the Kshs 10,000 she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, sugar and cooking fat oil. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, sugar and cooking fat oil.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace, 42, is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.
 
For the past three years she has operated a maize selling business, retailing to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of operation. Grace dreams of expanding her business and hiring more employees in the future.

With the Kshs 10,000 (Kenya shillings) she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, and sugar to sell. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, and sugar to sell.

loans.name: Ndoro

texts.en:
Ndoro 38, is a married man with six children, all of whom attend school. He owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past five years, Ndoro has operated a paraffin selling business, selling from home to his neighbors and passersby. He faces a major challenge from the high cost of transporting paraffin to his place of operation. He dreams of expanding his business to meet his customer demands in the future.

With the Kshs 15,000 Ndoro wants to purchase paraffin for sale. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: to purchase paraffin for sale.

loans.name: Mejumaa

texts.en:
Mejumaa 32, is a single mother of five girls, three of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past five years, Mejumaa has operated a food selling business, selling at the market to her neighbors and market dwellers. In addition she also operates a farming business which contributes to her other source of income. She faces a major challenge of competition in the market. Mejumaa dreams of establishing a charcoal selling business in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase stocks of wheat flour, maize flour, sugar and rice. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase stocks of wheat flour, maize flour, sugar and rice.

loans.name: Augusta

texts.en: This is 41 year-old Augusta.  She is married, and has 2 children ages 16 and 8. In 1997, Augusta established her pub and provision business. She began her business because after she graduated from school and got married, her husband requested that she start a business so that she could help to support their family. She opens her business 7 days a week and 15 hours a day. She would like a loan in the amount of Le 5,000,000. Augusta requires a loan in order to buy drinks for her bar. In the future, Augusta plans to open her business in other communities and be to help her husband pay university fees for their children.   She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more drinks for her pub

loans.name: Saidi

texts.en:
Saidi 28, is a married man with two children, ages four years and one year old. He owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past five years, Saidi has operated a food stall business, selling at the market to his neighbors and passersby. He dreams of establishing a retail shop business in the future. He dreams of accessing more loans to boost his business.

With the Kshs 20,000 he wants to purchase coffee for making tea and wheat flour for making Chapati(flat bread). He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: to purchase coffee for making tea and wheat flour for making Chapati(flat bread).

loans.name: Yelena

texts.en:
Yelena is divorced with two grown daughters. The company she had worked for downsized, and Yelena had to look for other work opportunities. That is how she decided to start her own venture. 

Today, Yelena owns a business selling athletic sportswear in the local market called “Yulana.” This is the only source of income for her family. Yelena has a nice assortment of inventory in her kiosk and has been in this trade for 12 years. Yelena is always innovative and dedicated to carrying merchandise with the newest popular brands and superior design. She always sells only the best quality sportswear that gives the right choice of comfort, fit, and style for her clients. Today Yelena is requesting a loan of 15,000 UAH to purchase additional merchandise. She’s hoping to expand her trade in the future and start selling athletic footwear too.

loans.use: to purchase seasonal merchandise

loans.name: Tunu

texts.en:
Tunu 45, is a single woman with four children, three of whom attend school. She owns a house that  has neither electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are for food and school fees. 

For the past four years, Tuna has operated a restaurant business, operating from the market to her neighbors and passersby. In addition she also operates a farming business which earns her additional  income. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of operation. Her major dream is to expand her business to meet her customer's needs in the future. 

With the Kshs 30,000 she wants to start a clothes business and wants to purchase bundles of clothes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Kazuki

texts.en:
Kazuki 58, is a married woman with nine children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past ten years, Kazuki has operated a green grocery business, selling retail to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of high cost of transportation and price fluctuation in her place of operation. Kazuki dreams of expanding and establishing another business in the future.

With the Kshs 40,000 Kazuki wants to purchase sacks of green vegetables for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of green vegetables for sale.

loans.name: Halima

texts.en:
Halima 40, is a married woman with seven children, all of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past ten years, Halima has operated a cereals selling business, selling at the market to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of price fluctuation of products. She dreams of purchasing a dairy cow to sell milk in the future.

With the Kshs 10,000 she wants to purchase maize, cow peas and beans. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase maize, cow peas and beans.

loans.name: David

texts.en: This is 35 year-old David. He is married, and has 1 child, age10. In 2006, David established his tailoring business. He began this business after training as a professional tailor. Working 7 days a week and 8 hours a day, he earns about Le 1,400,000 every month from this business. He would like a loan in the amount of Le 3,000,000. David requires a loan in order to buy different kinds of cloth and tailoring materials for his business. In the future, David plans to send his children to university and build a house. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy different kinds of cloth and tailoring materials for his business.

loans.name: Penninah

texts.en:
Penninah 60, is married with four children, two of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. 

For the past two years, Penninah has operated a charcoal and firewood selling business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of price fluctuation in the market. She dreams of establishing another business in the future.

With the Kshs 10,000 she wants to purchase sacks of charcoal for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma, 64, is a married woman with seven children, all of whom graduated from school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past four years, she has operated a goat meat selling business, selling at the market to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of high cost of transportation in her business. Her dream is to expand her business and improve her living standards.

With the Kshs 35,000 she wants to purchase goats for meat sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase goats for sale as meat.

loans.name: Joyce Wanjiru

texts.en:
Joyce is 30 years old, married, and has two daughters aged seven and ten years. She describes herself as an honest, efficient and effective woman. She has been selling poultry and raising cows for the last eleven years. Her business is faced with the problem of fluctuation prices of the poultry. 

Joyce will use the loan of Kes 20,000 to buy more chicks. Joyce hopes in the next five years she will have diversified her business, set a good example to fellow farmers, and irrigated her farm.

loans.use: To buy more chicks.

loans.name: Saumu

texts.en:
Saumu 48, is a married woman with six children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past two years, she has operated a retail shop business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. In addition she also operates a business selling farm produce which earns her another source of income. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the Kshs 10,000 she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, sugar and salt. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, sugar and salt.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma, 51, is a married woman with seven children, four of whom still attend school. She lives in a rental house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past six years, she has operated a "chapati" (flat bread) baking business. She sells at the market to her neighbours and passersby. Fatuma faces a major challenge in the low number of customers that turn up in the business. She dreams of establishing a restaurant business in the future.

With the Kshs 10,000 she wants to purchase wheat flour, cooking fat and charcoal. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase wheat flour, cooking fat and charcoal.

loans.name: Monicah Wanjiku

texts.en:
Monicah is 33 years old and married   to a businessman. They have two children aged two and six years. She describes herself as an aggressive businesswoman. 

Monicah has been selling clothes, curtains and bedcovers to frequent and new customers for the last four years. Her business is faced with the problem of inadequate funds to add to the stock of clothes. 

Monicah will use the loan of Kes 50,000 to add stock of clothes. In the future, Monicah wants to  be a wholesaler in selling clothes.

loans.use: To buy skirts, blouses, ladies' trousers and inner wear.

loans.name: Loice

texts.en:
Loice 35, is a married woman with six children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past two years, she has operated a cereals business, selling at the market to her neighbors and passersby. She dreams of expanding her business to cover a large market area in the future.

With the Kshs 10,000 she wants to purchase sacks of maize, beans and rice for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of maize, beans and rice for sale.

loans.name: Mwanamisi

texts.en:
Mwanamisi is a married woman with three children, two of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past two years, she has operated a vegetable selling business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of competition from other vegetable sellers in the area. She dreams of expanding her business to meet her customers' demand in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase sacks of vegetables, onions, potatoes, and cabbages for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of vegetables, onions, potatoes, and cabbages for sale.

loans.name: Zena

texts.en:
Zena is a divorced woman with three children, two of whom attend school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past four years, she has operated a clothes business, selling from door to door to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of price fluctuation in her business. She dreams of establishing a shop to sell clothes in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase bales of clothes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Habel

texts.en: Habel is a hardworking business man aged 32. He is married and blessed with three children, and two of them are in school. He does vehicle repairs to earn a living. He has employed two people to assist him in the business. Habel has been able to retain his business because of good reputation with his customers. He has requested a loan of 40,000 Kenya shillings to buy a welding machine. He express gratitude to Faulu Kenya for training him on good customer service. In the next five years, he wants to expand his business.

loans.use: To buy a welding machine.

loans.name: David Maina

texts.en:
David is married and has a two-year-old son. He describes himself as a determined and God-fearing man. He has been a mason for the last six years. In addition, he also sells shoes to add another source of income. His business of masonry is risky as he says and he has been faced with the problem of inadequate funds to get insurance covering the masonry products and himself. 

David will use the loan of Kes 20,000 to buy more building blocks. In the future, David hopes to employ sub-contractors.

loans.use: To buy building blocks.

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en:
Hellen has been operating a salon for six years.  The 29-year-old lady works hard in her business to provide for her child.  She has employed one person in the business to assist her in her tasks.  She also does farming to supplement her income.

She hopes to grow her business to generate more income in the future.  She has requested 80,000 Kenya shillings to buy hair braids, weaves and nail polish.

loans.use: To buy Hair braids, weaves and nail polish

loans.name: Saumu

texts.en: Saumu is taking another Kiva loan of KES 20,000 to start a cashew nut selling business. With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase sacks of cashew nuts to sell. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future. The previous loan helped her improve her business and increase her monthly profits by 50 percent.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of cashew nuts to sell.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en: Fatuma is taking another Kiva loan of KES 40,000 to boost her business. With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to purchase bundles for wheat flour, maize flour and rice. She dreams of expanding her business to meet her customer demand in the future. The previous loan helped her improve her business and improve the family's living standards.

loans.use: to purchase bundles for wheat flour, maize flour and rice.

loans.name: Zachary

texts.en:
Zachary is 56 years old.  He sells sand so as to earn a living.  He has been in the business for more than ten years and has employed two people.  He also owns rental houses.  Besides that, he does farming.  

Since he joined Faulu Kenya, he has managed to boost his farming by buying a water tank. He has also learnt how to save his money.  Zachary has requested a loan of 20,000 Kenya shillings to buy another water tank.

loans.use: To buy a water tank.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy tea leaves and paper for packaging.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is 36 years old and a single mother of one.  She runs a salon so as to earn a living.  She has been in this business for thirteen years.  She also does farming to supplement her income.  Through Faulu Kenya, she has learned how to save her money.  

She hopes to become a prosperous business-lady in the future.  She has requested 20,000 Kenya shillings to buy hair braids and cosmetics.

loans.use: to buy hair braids and cosmetics.

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy is a married woman with two children, both of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past two years, she has operated a cereals selling business, selling to various schools. She faces a major challenge of lack of enough capital to buy cereals. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

With the Kshs 10,000 she wants to purchase sacks of maize, beans, and rice. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of maize, beans, and rice.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase cement and sand to renovate her real estate houses.

loans.name: Loyce

texts.en:
Loyce is a married woman with two children, both of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. For the past three years, she has operated a business selling shoes from door-to-door to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of lack of enough capital in her business. She dreams of establishing a shop to sell shoes in the future.

With this 35,000 Kenyan shilling loan she wants to purchase shoes and clothes for sale during the festive season. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase shoes and clothes for sale during the festive season.

loans.name: Miselemani

texts.en:
Miselemani is a married woman with five children, three of whom attend school while two are adults. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. For the past four years, she has operated a business selling firewood from home to her neighbours and passersby. In addition, she sells fish which contributes another source of income. 

With this 20,000 Kenyan shilling loan, she wants to purchase bundles of firewood for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of firewood for resale.

loans.name: Mwanakombo

texts.en:
Mwanakombo is a married woman with five children, two of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. For the past ten years, she has operated a food stall, selling at the market and from home to her neighbours and passersby. Mwanakombo faces the major challenge of competition from other food stall operators in the area. She dreams of establishing a food stall business. 

With this 30,000 Kenyan shilling loan, she wants to purchase cooking fat oil, wheat flour and sugar. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase cooking fat oil, wheat flour and sugar.

loans.name: Savoeuy's Group

texts.en:
Savoeuy, 26, is married with one son who is in primary school. He is a peasant living in a rural village located in the Ratanak Mondul district. He plants red maize to make a living, and sometimes he works for others for additional income. 

After his first loan with VisionFund, Savoeuy and his group members (who have been with VisionFund from one to four years) are now applying for another loan. He wants to use this loan to pay for labor to harvest his maize. He hopes to increase his maize crop and also to sell it for a good price. He wants to generate a better income to improve his family's standard of living and also to keep his son in school.

loans.use: to pay for labor to harvest his maize

loans.name: John

texts.en: John, 23 years old, is single and has no children yet. He describes himself as a self-motivated man. He sells clothes, curtains, bed covers, shower caps, etc. In addition, he provides motorcycle transportation services. He has been in this business for one year and has one employee. His challenge is limited space in his area of business operation. He will use this loan of 50,000 Kenyan shillings to buy dozens of clothes and bed covers. John hopes and dreams to be a supplier of clothes in the future.

loans.use: to buy dozens of clothes and bed covers.

loans.name: Mwanaiki

texts.en:
Mwanaiki is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past four years, she has operated a cosmetic shop business selling cosmetics door to door and to neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of high cost of purchasing cosmetics for her business. She dreams of expanding to a wholesale shop in the future.

With the Kshs 15,000 she wants to purchase cosmetic for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase cosmetic for sale.

loans.name: Sovannsam's Group

texts.en:
Sovannsam, aged 41, is a married father of four children who are still in school. He lives in a rural area where crop farming is common. He has been growing maize for more than ten years to support his living. 

Sovannsam started taking loans from VisionFund three years ago. The loans have helped him to have regular income to feed his children and send them to school. Given a better living and good business, he and his group members, who has been with VisionFund for one year, are requesting another loan. He will use this loan to pay for labor in harvesting his maize crops. This loan will enable him to increase his maize crops and he hopes to sell them for a good price and then set aside some money for the future and also to keep his children in school.

loans.use: To pay for labor in harvesting his maize crops.

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth is married and has two children in school.  To earn a living, she sells cereals.  She has been in the business for three years and has employed one person.  Previously, she used to farm to earn a living.
  
She hopes to expand her business for more income generation in the future.  She has requested 65,000 Kenya shillings to buy cereals.

loans.use: to buy cereals.

loans.name: Mwanaisha

texts.en:
Mwanasha is a married woman with three children, two of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past four years, she has operated a vegetable stall business from home selling to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of competition from other vegetable stall operators. Mwanasha dreams of establishing a retail shop in the future.

With the Kshs 15,000 she wants to purchase kerosene for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase kerosene for sale.

loans.name: Sreyneat's Group

texts.en:
Originally from a rural area of the Ratanak Mondul district, Sreyneat is 31 years old and has made her living as a peasant who grows maize and peanuts. She has been in this business for more than three years. She has four children who help her work on the farm. 

Sreyneat leads a group of two female members who are with VisionFund this loan cycle. She wants to use the entire loan to pay for labor in harvesting maize crop and plowing her farmland, and to buy maize seeds for her farm. She hopes this loan will enable her to increase her maize crop and prepare land for planting. Also, she hopes to sell the crops for a good price to earn more income to live better.

loans.use: To pay for labor in harvesting maize crop and plowing her farmland.

loans.name: Sophy's Group

texts.en:
Sophy is 39 years old, married, and has five children who are still in school. To earn a living, Sophy has been growing maize and rice for five years in a village located in the Ratanak Mondul district. Her husband helps raise the family’s income by working as a teacher in the village. Sophy's previous loan in 2010 helped her to have regular income and send her children to school. 

With good business, she leads a group of three members who have, since 2010, been applying for another loan been with the VisionFund. She will use the entire loan to buy maize seeds and fertilizer for her farm. She hopes to increase her business so she can earn a larger income and live better.

loans.use: To buy maize seeds and fertilizer for her farm,

loans.name: Horm's Group

texts.en:
Horm, 42, is a married mother of six children, several of whom are still in school. She has been growing maize, pepper, and sesame for nearly thirty years to make a living. Sometimes she works for others to generate additional income. 

After three loan cycles with VisionFund, Horm has regular income to sufficiently feed her children and is able to send her children to school. Now she and her group members, who are just with VisionFund, are requesting a loan. She wants to buy crop seeds for her farm and will use some of the loan to pay for labor to plow her farmland. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her business and earn a larger income to live better.

loans.use: to buy crop seeds for her farm and use some of the loan to pay for labor to plow her farmland.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is 53 years old and has five children. To earn a living, she sells clothes. She has been in this business for twenty years and has employed one person. She also does poultry farming for more income generation.  

Since she joined Faulu Kenya her business has grown, thanks to Faulu Kenya's financial support.

Jane has requested 80,000 Kenya shillings to buy clothes.

loans.use: to buy clothes.

loans.name: Yorn's Group

texts.en:
Yorn is 43 years old and has three children working for others in grinding maize for fees. For more than ten years, she has been growing maize as her main income source to feed her children. Sometimes she works for others to raise additional income. 

Yorn leads a group of four female members applying for their first loan while her group members have been with VisionFund for one to two years. Now requesting a loan, she will use it to buy agricultural tools i.e. hoes, plows, etc for her farming. This loan will enable her to have sufficient tools to increase her business and she also hopes to make a good profit from this business in order to better feed her children.

loans.use: To buy agricultural tools for her farming.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase rubber dishes for her business.

loans.name: Fetna

texts.en:
Fetna used to be an employee in the Ministry of Health till she recently retired and started making pickles at home for sale. This has been going on for four years now. Year by year, Fetna make more types of pickles based, of course, on the season. Spicy olive pickles and cucumber pickles are the most ordered.

For now, Fetna wants to increase the quantity of pickles she makes and sells to the food markets, until she can open her own pickles store. In order to do that, Fetna decided to apply for a loan to buy more vegetables and containers to start providing the market with her product.

Fetna, a 51-year-old lady, is married and has two sons and a daughter.

loans.use: to buy more vegetables and containers to start providing the market with her product.

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en: Ruth is 24 years old and lives in Buchanan. She is married and her husband is a university student. They have four children between the ages of 5 to 10, all of them are attending school and live at home. For the past seven years she has been selling bitter balls in bags in the market. She has more customers and makes more profit. She is requesting a loan to purchase additional bags of bitter balls for her business. Ruth's plan is to build a house.

loans.use: to purchase additional bags of bitter balls for her business.

loans.name: Paula Jaymee

texts.en:
Paula Jaymee is a 26 year old married woman from Panglao, Bohol. She has a four year old child. Paula Jaymee sells rice cakes, bananas, and camote (sweet potato) cue in her community. She started this business a year ago. Paula Jaymee also provides hair-rebonding services to the people in her community. She is able to support her family through her ventures.

Paula Jaymee has requested a loan to purchase raw ingredients and hair rebonding materials. Paula Jaymee hopes to have a stable business in the future.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients and hair rebonding materials.

loans.name: Ludmila

texts.ru: Людмила хочет взять кредит, чтобы приобрести зимний ассортимент детской и подростковой одежды - кофты- 30 шт., куртки - 50 шт., брюки -50 шт. , теплые куртки -30шт. Предыдущий кредит содействовал развитию бизнеса. Людмила разширила свою торговую точку и увеличила оборот почти в 1,5 раза. Дом, который Людмила построила вмести со свои мужем, они сейчас доделывают (проводят отделочные работы внутри) и планируют в конце следующего года переехать туда.
texts.en: Ludmila would like to receive a loan in order to purchase a selection of children's and teen winter clothing, including 30 blouses, 50 jackets, 50 pairs of slacks, and 30 winter coats. The prior loan helped her grow her business, and she has expanded her shop and increased sales volume nearly 1 1/2 times.  She and her husband are currently putting the finishing touches on the house they built (they're finishing up the inside), and they plan to move in at the end of next year.

loans.use: to broaden her selection of winter clothing.

loans.name: Millicent

texts.en: Millicent, 40 years old, is a single woman with a 13-year-old son. She describes herself as a self-motivated woman. She has been selling shoes for the last 11 years and has one employee. Her business is located in a busy market. Her business challenge is a shortage of shoes from her supplier. She will use this 40,000 Kenyan shilling loan to buy more new shoes. Millicent's hopes and dreams are to be selling shoes wholesale and to venture into a new hardware business in the future.

loans.use: to buy more new shoes.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes  lives in Uganda. She is married and has 3 children, two of whom are in school. Agnes has had a pub for 5 years, and she works 6 days out of every week Agnes has requested a loan of 700,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more buy more crates of beer, soda and jerycans of local gin. The main business challenge(s) for Agnes include seasonality and thieves. Her goals and aspirations for her business are seeing her business grow big and start selling wholesale, and also to own a fully stocked pub. Agnes lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity and to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees, medication and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more crates of beer, soda and jerycans of local gin

loans.name: Zainab

texts.en:
Zainab, a 56-year-old widow, has a son and a daughter to raise. 

To be able to support herself and her family she started to make different types of covers, clothes and scarves from wool and sell them.

Now Zainab has applied for a loan to buy more wool and more material to expand her knitting business and make more items for sale

loans.use: to buy more wool and more materials to expand her knitting business and make more items for sale.

loans.name: Betty

texts.en: Betty lives in Uganda. She is married and has 6 children, all of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members (in-laws). Betty has a business selling charcoal. She has been in this business for over 8 years, and she works 6 days out of every week. Betty sells her products from home, retail. Betty has requested a loan of 600,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO to buy more bags of charcoal. The main business challenge(s) for Betty include seasonality and thieves. Her goals and aspirations for her business are seeing her business grow big and also to own 2000 chicken and start selling wholesale. Betty lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees, medication and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose lives in Uganda. She is widowed and has 6 children, all of whom are in school. Rose has a business selling charcoal. She has been in this business for over 5 years, and she works 6 days out of every week.  Rose sells her products retail at the market and has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO to buy more bags of charcoal. She also generates additional income through frying chapat. The main business challenge(s) for Rose include seasonality and thieves. Her goals and aspirations for her business are seeing her business grow big, acquire a delivery van and  also start selling wholesale. Rose lives in a home that she owns with access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees, utility bills and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Felecia

texts.en: Felecia  is 36 years old and lives in  Buchanan, Liberia. She is married and has five children between one and 18, four of them in school and all live at home. For the past 20 years she has been selling  palm oil, dishes, and used clothes. She started this business with palm oil that she received  from her mother, and has increased the number of customers. She is requesting a loan to purchase more palm oil, dishes, and used clothes for her business and plans is to build a house in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase palm oil, dishes, and used clothes  for her business

loans.name: Svetlana

texts.en:
Svetlana is married with a grown daughter. She is a small-scale entrepreneur from Znamenka. Svetlana grows rareripes, (i.e. tomatoes and radishes) for sale in one of the local markets in her home town. Svetlana started this trade 16 years ago. Currently, she has 25,000 Grivnyas invested in her farm. Annually Svetlana spends about 8,000 – 13,000 Grivnyas  — on seeds and polyethylene film.
 
Svetlana is requesting a loan of 5,000 Grivnyas to purchase a variety of clear, white and thermal films in different thicknesses for her greenhouses. She is planning to invest generated funds in further development of her business and construction of additional greenhouses on her plot of land.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and polyethylene greenhouse covering

loans.name: Resty

texts.en:
Resty lives in Uganda.  She is married and has one child who is not in school.  She has a retail shop business selling used shoes, clothes, and phone accessories.  She has been in this business for four years, and she works six days out of every week. Resty sells her products in a shop, by means of retail.  

Resty has requested a loan from MCDT SACCO for 400,000 Ugandan Shillings, which she will use to buy more airtime (for phones), used shoes, and clothes. 

She also generates additional income through making women's beads. The main business challenges for Resty include seasonality and thieves.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to see her business grow big, to own a fully stocked shop, and to start selling wholesale.

Resty lives in a home that she rents and she has access to electricity and piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include rent, medication, and feeding the family.

loans.use: to buy more used shoes, clothes, and phone accessories.

loans.name: Mesalimu

texts.en:
Mesalimu is a married woman with four children, three of whom attend school, while one is still young for school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past five years, she has operated a dressmaking business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of operation. 

During festive season, the month of December, the demand for dresses is very high compared to other months when demand is low. She dreams of expanding her business to meet her customer demand in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase bales of cloth materials for dressmaking business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bales of cloth materials for dressmaking business.

loans.name: Paul Musembi

texts.en:
Paul is married and has three children ranging from 14 to 22 years old. He describes himself as an honest man. 

Paul has been selling beans, peas, maize flour and rice for the last five years. His business faces a challenge with financial constraints, which makes it hard for him to be able to add to the stock of cereals. He will be using the loan Kes 20,000 to buy more rice and beans.

Paul hopes in the future to start a new maize milling business and to own a cereal house where he will be distributing all types of flour.

loans.use: To purchase rice and beans.

loans.name: Mwanaidi

texts.en:
Mwanaidi is a married woman with four children, three of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past two years, she has operated a retail business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of competition from other retail shop operators in her business. Mwanaidi dreams of establishing a retail shop in the future.

With the KES 10,000 loan, she wants to purchase wheat flour, maize flour, sugar and cooking fat oil.  Mwanaidi decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase wheat flour, maize flour, sugar and cooking oil.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a married woman with three children, two of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

Fatuma is requesting a loan of KES 10,000 to start a cashew nut selling business. She wants to sell at the market to market buyers and passersby. She dreams of expanding her business to increase her profit.

With the KES 20,000 loan, she wants to purchase a sack of cashew nuts for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase a sack of cashew nuts for sale.

loans.name: Kibibi

texts.en:
Kibibi, 27, is a single woman who stays at a family house that has piped water but not electricity. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees for her young siblings.

For the past two years, she has operated a boutique business, selling to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of operation. She dreams of expanding her business to meet her customer needs 

With the KES 50,000 loan, she wants to purchase bales of clothes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a married woman with three children, two of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

Fatuma is requesting a loan of KES 10,000 to start a cashew nut selling business. She wants to sell at the market to market buyers and passersby. She dreams of expanding her business to increase her profit.

With the KES 10,000 loan, she wants to purchase a sack of cashew nuts for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase a sack of cashew nuts for sale.

loans.name: Naomi

texts.en:
Naomi is 24 years old and lives in Buchanan; she is single and has a 2 year-old child. 

For six  years now, Naomi has been operating a salon where she plaits and dresses hair.  She is requesting a loan to purchase more material (artificial hair) for her business.  She hopes to build a house.

loans.use: to purchase artificial hair for her business

loans.name: Faith

texts.en:
Faith  lives in Uganda.  She is married and has five children, four of whom are in school.  She also takes care of additional family members. Faith has a business selling tomatoes.  She has been in this business for two years, and she works 6 days out of every week. Faith sells her products at the market, retail.     

Faith has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more boxes of tomatoes. The main business challenges for Faith   include transportation, perishability, and seasonality.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to see her business grow big and start selling wholesale only and also start growing tomatoes herself           

 Faith   lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity but doesn't have access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family

loans.use: To buy more boxes of tomatoes.

loans.name: Nzungwa

texts.en:
Nzungwa, 37, is a single mother of two children who both attend school. She lives in a rental house that has piped water but not electricity. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past five years, she has operated a retail shop business, selling to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, rice and sugar. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, rice and sugar.

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis is a married man. He has two children aged 6 years and 10 years. He describes himself as an optimistic man. He provides motorcycle transportation services. He has been involved in this business for two years. In addition, he does farming to increase his income. His business is located near a shopping centre. He faces a challenge of insufficient funds for maintaining the business.

Francis will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy spare parts for the motorcycle. His business goal is to triple his business income within 5 years.

loans.use: To buy motorcycle spare parts.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah  lives in Uganda.  She is married and has five children, four of whom are in school.  She also takes care of additional family members (her father).  Sarah  has a business selling maize (popcorn). She has been in this business for two years, and she works 6 days out of every week. 

Sarah sells her products door-to-door, retail. She has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of maize and a jerrycan of cooking   oil. The main business challenges for Sarah include transportation and the rainy season which makes it hard for her to get around.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own another popcorn machine and employ two girls to ease her work.   

Sarah lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity but doesn't have access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more bags of maize and cooking oil.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret 48, is a married woman with two children, both of whom attend school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past two years, she has operated a vegetable stall, selling at the market to her neighbours and passersby. She dreams of establishing a wholesale stall for vegetables in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase sacks of vegetables, potatoes and onions. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of vegetables, potatoes, and onions.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth 36, is a single mother of one child who attends school. She lives in a rental house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past the past sixteen years, she has operated a retail shop business, selling to her neighbours and passersby. In addition she also operates a tailoring business, her other source of income. She dreams of establishing a boutique in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase stock of wheat flour, maize flour and sugar. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase stock of wheat flour, maize flour and sugar.

loans.name: Mwanatumu

texts.en:
Mwanatumu, 25, is a single mother of two children, both of whom attend school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past two years, she has operated a palm wine selling business, selling from home to her neighbours and passerby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of operation. She dreams of becoming the main supplier of palm wine in the future.

With the Kshs 10,000 she wants to purchase coconuts for making palm wine. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase coconuts for making palm wine.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane 48, is a single mother of three children, two of whom have finished school while one still attends school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past ten years, she has operated a butcher shop, selling to town dwellers and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She dreams of establishing a restaurant business in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase cow meat for sale at the butcher shop. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase cow meat for sale at the butcher shop.

loans.name: Nyevu

texts.en:
Nyevu, 44, is a married woman with seven children, five of whom attend school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water.  Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past ten years, she has operated a business selling palm wine made from coconuts, selling to her neighbours. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. Her dream is to become a main supplier in the future.

With the Kshs 10,000 she wants to purchase sacks of coconuts for making palm wine for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of coconuts for making palm wine for sale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more red oil (palm oil) for her business.

loans.name: Hamadi

texts.en: Hamadi is taking out another Kiva loan of KES 40,00O to boost his video cafe business. With the loan, he wants to expand the video room and purchase audio speakers. He dreams of expanding his business to meet the customers' needs.

loans.use: to expand the video room and purchase audio speakers.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah lives in Uganda.  She is married and has two children, both of whom are in school.  She also takes care of additional family members (her father).  Sarah  has a business selling bananas.  She has been in this business for over 10 years, and she works 6 days out of every week.

Sarah   sells her products from home, retail.  Sarah has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bunches of bananas.  The main business challenges for    Sarah    include thieves and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to   see her business grow big and start selling wholesale only and also to build her own house. 

Sarah lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity and piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees, paying utility bills and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas.

loans.name: Renson

texts.en:
Renson, 29, is married with one child who attends school. He owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. His greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past eight years, he has operated a barber shop; his potential customers are neighbours and passersby. He also operates a vegetable stall with the support of his wife Tina. Renson faces a major challenge of seasonality in the business.

With the Kshs 40,000 he wants to purchase another hair cutting machine. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: to purchase another hair-cutting machine.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John, 28, is single and lives in a rental house that neither has electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expense is paying the rent.

For the past year, he has operated a retail shop business, selling to his neighbours and passersby. He faces a major challenge of seasonality in his business. He dreams of expanding his business in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 he wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour and sugar. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour and sugar.

loans.name: Mitsanze

texts.en:
Mitsanze is a married man with three children, all of whom attend school. He lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. His greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past year, he has operated a printing shop business. His potential customers are neighbours and passersby. He faces a major challenge of seasonality in his business. He dreams of establishing other businesses in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 he wants to purchase five reams of printing papers for his business. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: to purchase five reams of printing papers for his business.

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel, 33, is a married man with two children, both of whom attend school. He lives in a rental house that has neither electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past year, he has operated a grocery shop business, operating from the market where town-dwellers are his potential customers. He faces a major challenge of seasonality in his place of operation. Samuel dreams of establishing another business in the future.

With the Kshs 15,000, he wants to purchase sacks of vegetables for resale. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of vegetables for resale

loans.name: Chiro

texts.en:
Chiro, 37, is single and lives in a rental house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food.

For the past year, she has operated a clothes-selling business, selling at the market to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of competition from other clothes sellers in the market. Chiro dreams of establishing other businesses in the future.

With the Kshs 5,000, she wants to purchase bales of clothes for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes for sale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase sacks of green vegetables, potatoes, tomatoes and onions

loans.name: Nulu

texts.en:
Nulu lives in Uganda. She is married and has 3 children, all of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members (two sisters and a brother). 

Nulu has a business of selling charcoal. She has been in this business for over 10 years, and she works 6 days out of every week. Nulu sells her products from home. Nulu has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of charcoal. She also generates additional income through rental houses.

The main business challenges for Nulu include thieves and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to see her business grow big, start selling through wholesale only and also to educate her children up to the university level. Nulu lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees, paying utility bills and feeding the family.

loans.use: to buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Geoffrey

texts.en:
Geoffrey is a married man with one child who is still too young for school. He lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past year, he has operated a retail shop business, selling at the market to his neighbours and passersby. He dreams of establishing another business in the future. 

With the Kshs 20,000, he wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, sugar and cooking fat oil. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, sugar and cooking fat oil

loans.name: Sanu Maiya

texts.en:
Sanu Maiya is 50 years old.  She is married and has one child, aged 20. In 1998, she established her grocery store business. Working seven days a week and 10 hours a day, she supports her family. She has already received and successfully repaid seven loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent loan to buy grocery goods for her business. In the future, Sanu Maiya plans to uplift the economic condition of her family.  She thanks you for your support. 

In the Kathmandu Valley, the small grocery store, called a pasal, is an important part of the local economy.  Fresh produce, milk, and staples such as rice, lentils, and flour are purchased daily for cooking in the home. Owners of small grocery stores use Kiva loans to increase their purchasing power and profit margins.  By keeping inventory strong and purchasing in larger amounts, owners of these small stores are able to increase their profitability. While a typical pasal might be no more than 100 sq. feet, they are always full of bargaining customers, incoming produce, and shrewd businesswomen.

loans.use: to buys grocery goods

loans.name: George

texts.en:
George is a widowed man with one child who attends school. He lives at a rental house that has neither electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past year, he has operated a grocery-selling business, selling at the market to his neighbors and passersby. He faces a major challenge of seasonality in his business. He dreams of establishing another business in the future.

With the KES 20,000 loan, he wants to purchase sacks of tomatoes and green vegetables for sale. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of tomatoes and green vegetables for sale.

loans.name: Sofia

texts.en:
Sofia 31, is a married woman with one child who attends school. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food and school fees for the family.

For the past three years, she has operated a retail shop business, selling at retail to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of theft because of insecurity in her place of operation. Sofia dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the Kshs 10,000 loan, she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, sugar and rice. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, sugar and rice.

loans.name: Nira

texts.en:
Nira is 31 years old.  She is married and has one child, aged 13.  In 2001, she established her tea shop business.  Working 7 days a week and 10 hours a day, she supports her family.  She has already received and successfully repaid 5 loans from Patan BPW.  She used her most recent loan to buy food materials for her business.  

In the future, Nira plans to improve the economic condition of her family.  She thanks you for your support. 

Whether on the streets of Kathmandu or in the villages outside of the capital, tea shops are places of business and meeting in Nepal.  Called a chiya pasal, a tea shop makes a sweet, milky tea that can be purchased for a few cents a cup.  With a Kiva loan, BPW's borrowers are able to keep their store shelves stocked while increasing their profit margins by buying in greater volume.

loans.use: to buy food materials for her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more used clothes for her business

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice is a married woman with four children, three of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past year, she has operated a retail shop business, selling to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of operation. She dreams of expanding to a wholesale shop in future.

With the KES 10,000 loan, she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour and sugar for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour and sugar for sale.

loans.name: Purity

texts.en:
Purity is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past three years, she has operated a vegetable stall business, selling at the market to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She dreams of hiring more employees in the future.

With the 20,000 she wants to purchase sacks of tomatoes, green vegetables and onions. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of tomatoes, green vegetables and onions.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is a married woman, living in a rental house that has electricity, but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and rent bills.

For the past one year, she has operated a vegetable stall business at the market, selling to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop of vegetables in the future.

With the Kshs 50,000 she wants to purchase sacks of vegetables for resale at her stall. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of vegetables for resale at her stall.

loans.name: Rabina

texts.en:
Rabina is 36 years old . She is married and has 2 children, aged 19 and 17. In 2000, she established her grocery store business. She works 7 days a week and 10 hours a day to support her family.

She has already received and successfully repaid 5 loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent loan to buy groceries for her business. In the future, Rabina plans to uplift the economic condition of her family. She thanks you for your support. In the Kathmandu Valley, a small grocery store, called a 'pasal', is an important part of the local economy. Fresh produce, milk, and staples such as rice, lentils, and flour are purchased daily for cooking in the home. Owners of small grocery stores use Kiva loans to increase their purchasing power and profit margins. By keeping inventory strong and purchasing in larger amounts, owners of these small stores are able to increase their profitability. While a typical 'pasal' might be no more than 100 sq. feet, they are always full of bargaining customers, incoming produce, and shrewd businesswomen.

loans.use: to buys inventory for her grocery store.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to install water pipes in her house.

loans.name: Katwii

texts.en:
Katwii, 31, is a married woman with two children, both of whom attend school. She lives at a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are rent bills and food for the family.

For the past five years, she has operated a food stall business, selling to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of operation.  Katwii dreams of expanding her business to meet her customer demand in the future.

With the 30,000 Kenya shillings (KES) she wants to purchase food stock of maize flour and wheat flour, and also cooking pots. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase food stock of maize flour, wheat flour, and cooking pots.

loans.name: Malieta

texts.en:
Malieta is a married woman with one child who is still too young for school. She lives at a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are rent bills.

For the past five years, she has operated a clothes selling business, selling in a shop to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of operation. She dreams of expanding to a wholesale shop in the future.

With the 30,000 Kenya shillings (KES) she wants to purchase bales of clothes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Shanta

texts.en:
Shanta is 50 years old. She is married and has two children, aged 28 and 21. 

In 2000, she established her business selling cow's milk.  Working seven days a week and four hours a day, she supports her family.  She has already received and successfully repaid seven loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent loan to buy a young milk-giving cow.  In the future, Shanti plans to uplift the economic condition of her family.  She thanks you for your support. 

Dairy cows are an important source of nutrition and income in Nepal.  Cows are never raised for beef, but for their milk, from which curd (duy) and fresh cheese (paneer) are made.  Jersey cows are the preferred breed for milking.  On average, a dairy cow in Nepal will produce about 10 liters of milk each day.  In the local market, a liter of milk sells for about USD $0.50.  In addition to producing milk, cows provide dung that is used in home construction, as fuel for fires, and for methane production.  

The purchase of a dairy cow, made possible through a Kiva loan, is an investment that will repay itself many times over.

loans.use: to buy a young milk-giving cow.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is married with four children, all of whom graduated from school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past six month, she has operated a business of selling omena (dry fish) to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of high cost of transportation in the business. She dreams of becoming a main (key) supplier in the future.

With the Kshs 30,000 she wants to purchase sacks of omena (dry fish) for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of omena (dry fish) for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more used clothes for her business

loans.name: Mwanahalima

texts.en:
Mwanahalima is a married woman with two children, both of whom attend school. She lives at a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and rent bills.

For the past two years, she has operated a food stall selling business, selling to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of operation. Her major dream is to establish a large business in the future.

With the Kshs 10,000 she wants to purchase a stock of wheat flour, maize flour, rice, and cooking pots. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase a stock of wheat flour, maize flour, rice, and cooking pots.

loans.name: Julia

texts.en:
Julia lives in Uganda. She is single and has one child, who goes to school. She also takes care of additional family members (a niece).

Julia has a business of selling snacks (a restaurant). She has been in this business for five years, and she works six days out of every week. Julia sells her products door-to-door, by means of retail. 

Julia has requested a loan of 1,400,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of Irish potatoes, beef, chicken and a jerycan of cooking oil. The main business challenges for Julia include transportation and seasonality. 

Her goals and aspirations for her business are to get a permanent business premises and also to build her own house. Julia lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity and has access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees rent and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more bags of Irish potatoes, beef, chicken and a jerycan of cooking oil

loans.name: Edith

texts.en:
Edith, 43, is a married woman with five children, all of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past five years, she has operated a business selling tea leaves, selling from door to door to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of price fluctuation in her business. She dreams of establishing a shop to sell her products in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase more packets of tea leaves for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase more packets of tea leaves for sale.

loans.name: Yanett

texts.es: La Sra. Yanett vive en la zona del plan 3000  la casa donde viven es propia, tiene 32 años, no tienen hijos, la Sra. Yanett, se dedica a la venta de comida de lunes a jueves vende platillos como pollo de broaster, bife, milanesa e pollo, sopa de maní y variedad de platillos, su esposo  Willy  tiene 31 años, es pintor de viviendas, hace tres años que se dedica a  este oficio, el motivo del crédito la compra de material de construcción  para techado de  su negocio porque ya es temporada de lluvias y esto le perjudica mucho en su venta por este motivo necesita el techado y también  ya esta implementando la venta de comida los  días  viernes, la Sra. Yanett es una persona muy trabajadora y se siente agradecida con la institución por el apoyo brindado.
texts.en:
Señora Yanett lives in map zone 3000. The house where they live is their own. She is 32 years old and has no children. Señora Yanett sells food. From Monday to Thursday she sells dishes such as broasted chicken, beef or chicken milanesa, peanut soup, and a variety of other dishes. Her husband, Willy, who is 31, paints houses; he has been doing this work for three years. 

The reason for the loan is to purchase construction material for the roof of her business, because it is now the rainy season and this hurts her sales a lot. For this reason she needs the roof. Also, she is now setting up the sale of food on Fridays. Señora Yanett is a very hard-working person, and she feels thankful to the institution for the support they have offered.

loans.use: to buy construction material for the roof of her business.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah lives in Uganda. She is single and has two children, both in school. She also takes care of her old parents. Sarah lives in a home that she rents. She has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees, paying utility bills and feeding the family.

Sarah has a business selling smoked fish. She has been in this business for five years. She works 6 days out of every week. Sarah sells her products retail at the market. She also generates additional income by selling roasted meat.

Sarah has requested a loan of 900,000 Ugandan shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more baskets of smoked fish. The main business challenges for Sarah include thieves, defaulters and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations are to see her business grow big and to start selling wholesale only. She wants to start going to Sese islands on Lake Victoria for fish and also to build her own house.

loans.use: to buy more baskets of smoked fish

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce, 26, is a married woman with one child who attends school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past four years, she has operated a business of selling deep fried potatoes at an open air market to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of the high cost of purchasing potatoes in the market. She dreams of expanding her business and establishing another business in the future.

With this 20,000 Kenyan shilling loan, she wants to purchase cooking fat oil, potatoes and flavors. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase cooking fat oil, potatoes and flavors.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more used clothes for her business

loans.name: Leonia

texts.en:
Leonia lives in Uganda.  She is single and has 6 children, two of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members (a cousin and her daughter).

Leonia has a pub business. She has been in this business for 7 years, and she works 7 days a week. Leonia sells her products from home, by retail.  She has requested a loan of 800,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more crates of beer and soda and jerrycans of local gin for the festive season.

She also generates additional income through selling piped water. The main business challenges for Leonia include thieves, defaulters and the rainy season.  Because she works in a muddy place, this hinders her customers from reaching out to her.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to see her business grow big and to own a fully stocked pub and also to educate her children up to university level.

Leonia lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity and to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees, paying utility bills and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more crates of beer and soda and jerrycans of local gin

loans.name: Jackelin

texts.es: La  señorita  Jackelin  nació en la ciudad de Cochabamba,  vive en  la  localidad de Santa Rita por más de 15 años. Ella  se  dedica a la venta  de Hamburguesa  y salchipapas en la localidad del torno por más de ocho años. Ella necesita el crédito para poder comprarse mas silla y mesas ya que quiere ampliar su negocio y también tiene un  carrito Hamburguesito, ella vive   con su madre y sus hermano es cliente antigua se encuentra pasando la su octava  secuencia. Ella dice que los crédito que se dan son agiles y oportuno porque siempre lo ayudan en el momento indicado, La Señorita Jackelin es muy responsable ya que con esta actividad se mantiene ella y mantiene  a su familia.
texts.en: Jackelin was born in the city of Cochabamba. She has lived in the town of Santa Rita for more than 15 years. Her business is selling hamburgers and salchipapas (Peruvian fast food). She has been in this business, in El Torno, for more than eight years. Jackelin needs this loan to buy more tables and chairs as she would like to expand her business. She also has a hamburger cart. She lives with her mother and her siblings. She is a long-standing client who is in her eighth loan cycle. She says that the loans she receives are versatile and timely because they always help her when she needs it. Jackelin is very responsible and her business supports both herself and her family.

loans.use: to buy tables and chairs to expand her sales location

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary, 53, is a married woman with four children, all of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are rent bills and school fees.

For the past seven years, she has operated a clothes-selling business, selling from door to door to her neighbors and passersby. She dreams of establishing and expanding her business to cover a large market area in the future.

With the KES 10,000 loan, she wants to purchase bales of clothes for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes for sale.

loans.name: Marylyne

texts.en:
Marylyne is a married woman with five children, all of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past year, she has operated a charcoal-selling business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of high cost of transportation in the business. She dreams of becoming a wholesale supplier in the future.

With the KES 60,000 loan, she wants to purchase sacks of charcoal for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of charcoal for sale.

loans.name: Mwikali

texts.en:
Mwikali is a married woman with six children, all of whom are grown up. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past four years, she has operated a greengrocery business, selling to local residents. In addition, she sells charcoal which contributes another source of income. She faces a major challenge of price fluctuation in her business. She dreams of becoming a wholesale supplier in the future.

With the KES 60,000 loan, she wants to purchase sacks of charcoal for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of charcoal for sale.

loans.name: Nazi

texts.en:
Nazi is a widow with seven children, all of whom are adults. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past five years, she has operated a fish business, selling door to door to her neighbors and passersby. Seasonality is a major challenge she faces in her place of operation. She dreams of expanding her business to meet customer demand in the future.

Nazi decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business. She wants to purchase bundles of fish for sale with a 10,000 KES loan.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of fish to sell.

loans.name: Emiliano

texts.es: El señor Emiliano  tiene 43 años, tiene seis hijitos que se encuentran en edad escolar y vive en la zona internacional, hace 14 años que se dedica a la venta de helados y los tres últimos meses del año empieza con la venta de cosas reciclables como ser botellas, latas de cervezas plásticos baterías y otros. Su esposa le colabora con la venta de los helados al igual que unas de sus hijas, el señor vende sus helados por todas las zonas de la ciudad de Santa Cruz de forma ambulante   y también sale a las diferentes provincias  aledañas de Santa Cruz, con el dinero del crédito comprara un motor para su moto y también botella y latas por mayor para poder venderlos como material reciclable, el Sr. Emiliano es una persona responsable y trabajadora con ganas de seguir adelante por el bienestar de sus hijos ya que desea brindarle un futuro mejor.
texts.en:
Emiliano, 43, has six little children who are school age and he lives in the International zone.  He’s been selling ice-cream for 14 years and the last three months of the year he sells recyclable items like bottles, beer cans, plastic, batteries and others.  His wife as well as one of his daughters helps him with the ice-cream sales in an itinerant way throughout all parts of the city of Santa Cruz.  He also goes out to various adjacent areas to the city of Santa Cruz.

With money from the loan he will buy an engine for his motorcycle and also bottles and cans at wholesale to resell as recyclable material.  Emiliano is a responsible, hardworking person who wants to continue forward for his children’s wellbeing because he wants to offer them a better future.

loans.use: to buy an engine for his motorcycle and to buy bottles, cans, plastic, etc.

loans.name: Laxmi

texts.en:
Laxmi is 40 years old.  She is married and has two children, aged 23 and 21. 
 
In 2001, she established her cow's milk selling business.  Working seven days a week and four hours a day, she supports her family.  She has already received and successfully repaid two loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent loan to buy a young milk-giving cow.  In the future, Laxmi plans to uplift the economic condition of her family.  She thanks you for your support. 

Dairy cows are an important source of nutrition and income in Nepal.  Cows are never raised for beef, but for their milk, from which curd (duy) and fresh cheese (paneer) are made.  Jersey cows are the preferred breed for milking.  On average, a dairy cow in Nepal will produce about 10 liters of milk each day.  In the local market, a liter of milk sells for about USD $0.50.  In addition to producing milk, cows provide dung that is used in home construction, as fuel for fires, and for methane production.  

The purchase of a dairy cow, made possible through a Kiva loan, is an investment that will repay itself many times over.

loans.use: to buy a young cow.

loans.name: Jacqueline Isabel

texts.es:
